Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dwarf Galaxies and the Nature of Dark Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
The nature of dark matter (DM) remains one of the leading unsolved problems in cosmology today, and absent any direct detection of the particles themselves, the structure of nearby dwarf galaxies remains one of the most promising avenues for learning about the temperature and self-interaction properties of DM because any deviations from the standard cold dark matter model should happen at low masses.

Modern ideas regarding how galaxies form in the Universe involve some form of "hierarchical" process by which small systems progressively merged into ever larger systems like our Milky Way Galaxy. A key element of this paradigm regards how mergers proceed, which, in turn, relies on understanding the nature of the DM needed to drive the formation of galaxies within the observed lifetime of the Universe. Dwarf galaxies are the smallest, simplest entities with DM that also contain visible baryonic material in the form of stars and/or gas. As such, they---and particularly their dark halos---represent our best local analogs of the building blocks that initiated the hierarchical process. The broad goal of this project is to use empirical techniques---primarily kinematic observations of stars in nearby dwarf galaxies---to determine key properties of DM halos in these systems in a largely model-independent way.

The specific aims of this project include (1) learning how DM is distributed within individual galaxies by measuring the central mass densities and core properties of DM halos, (2) exploring how the evolution of the baryonic matter may have altered the DM components in galaxies, (3) determining if DM halos are truly scale free, (4) mapping the extents of DM halos in dwarfs and understanding how their dark and visible components have merged into the greater halo of our Galaxy, and (5) laying the groundwork to reconstruct the properties of the primordial population of dwarfs that contributed to the assembly of our Galaxy. This project builds on decades of NSF-sponsored instrument building and research grants to aid our understanding of the nature of DM.

The investigators will engage in educational activities with several K-12 teachers, give public talks, and participate in events such as "Ask an Astronomer." The project will also support graduate student training throughout the grant period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outer regions of the Milky Way contain clumpy stellar structures in the form of dwarf galaxies and stellar streams (see Figure).  Dwarf galaxies are the smallest, least luminous and most dark-matter dominated systems known.  Stellar streams are the remnants of dwarf galaxies and/or star clusters that were accreted into the Milky Way and subsequently destroyed by tidal forces.  Both kinds of objects hold clues to the processes of galaxy formation and the nature of the mysterious dark matter that comprises most of the Universe's mass.  This project supported spectroscopic observations and analyses of dwarf galaxies and stellar streams within the Milky Way halo, conducted with the M2FS and Hectochelle spectrographs at the Magellan and MMT telescopes located in Chile and Arizona, respectively.

These observations provided many new data sets that measure the velocities, temperatures, sizes and chemistries of individual stars in dwarf galaxies and stellar streams, most of which were discovered only during the last four years.  Notable results include measurements of the masses of dwarf galaxies Reticulum 2, Tucana 2 and Grus 1, all of which are confirmed to be embedded within extended dark matter halos. Moreover, the identification of a massive dark matter halo in Reticulum 2 coincides with reported hints of gamma-ray emission from this object, offering the tantalizing possibility of detecting byproducts of dark matter particle annihilation. The project also yielded a large data set containing hundreds of stars for the relatively luminous dwarf galaxy Draco, providing a rare opportunity to study how dark matter is distributed within an individual dwarf galaxy.  The dwarf galaxy Crater 2 was measured to have dark matter and the lowest-density dark matter halo ever identified, challenging galaxy formation models to explain the origin of this object.  

Observations taken for this, and previous, NSF grants, over upwards of 20 years have been analyzed to determine the frequency of binary stars in halo dwarf galaxies.   The binary fractions of several dwarf galaxies were measured and found to vary by a large amount. These results reveal how binaries must be accounted for to not distort our conclusions regarding the masses and dark matter contents in these systems, an effect we are already seeing within some of the most recently discovered dwarf systems.

This project also supported the initiation of work to characterize the 'normal' mass-to-light ratios as a function of stellar population age and metallicities in systems--dense star clusters of the Magellanic Clouds--know to not contain any dark matter.  This empirical work is meant to complement and test theoretical studies, all of which will be crucial in interpreting the dark matter within nearby dwarf galaxies and to interpret the masses of distant galaxies for which only the luminous matter can be measured directly.

This project supported M2FS observations by the community of Magellan users, covering a wide range of science topics ranging from star formation to extra-solar planets to galaxy clusters to distant galaxies. Gradute students and postdocs at several institutions and not directly supported by this grant, benefited from the use of these instruments and from the expertise of the investigators.
